note.p: Hamilton Henderson Chalmers was an attorney and justice on the Mississippi Supreme Court in the nineteenth century.

Born on October 1, 1835, in Tennessee, Chalmers moved to Mississippi as a boy with his family. His family became active in politics and law, led by his father who served in the Mississippi legislature and most notably served in the U. S. Senate in the 1840s. Chalmers was well educated in Mississippi and became a practicing attorney in the state. During the Civil War, he served as an assistant adjutant general in the Confederate army. After the war, Chalmers returned to legal practice. In 1876 he was appointed to the Mississippi Supreme Court and served there until his death on January 3, 1885, after several months of poor health, at the age of 49.
He was married to Emily Erwin and had at least one child. Chalmers is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; The State Ledger, Jackson, MS, January 9, 1885)
Hamilton Henderson Chalmers belonged to the following social groups:
William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
William Lewis Sharkey belonged to the following social groups:
James Bright Morgan belonged to the following social groups:

Currently located in DeSoto County, Hernando was founded in the early 1830s under the name Jefferson in what were then Washington and Monroe counties and was renamed Hernando in 1832. When DeSoto County was created on March 1, 1836, Hernando became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 859-860; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Clarke County, De Soto was founded as early as 1845. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "The act of leaving a job or position and making a statement that you are doing this." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Amnesty takes several forms including: "a decision made by government officials to free a prisoner," "a fixed period of time during which people are not punished for committing a particular crime," or "a decision by a government to forgive people who have committed particular illegal acts or crimes, and not to punish them." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A large formal meeting of people who do a particular job or have a similar interest, or a large meeting for a political party." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A time when people vote in order to choose someone for a political or official job." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A person who oversees "the process of managing the property, money, etc. of someone who has died and giving it to the beneficiaries." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)

div.p:
Hernando De Soto Co Miss
Aug 9th 1865

Hon W. L. Sharkey
Govr of Miss

Mr J. C. Culbertson our present Sheriff having tendered his resignation of that posi-tion I would respectfully recommend Judge J. B. Mor-gan as a most suitable person to fill the vacancy thus occasioned until the regular election may be ordered by the convention
Mr Morgan was formerly Probate Judge of the county He is an active intelli-gent & highly responsible gentleman and I am satisfied that no more suitable or popular appointment could be made
He has taken the am-nesty oath & has ^also^ taken an active & leading part in the attempt to re-organize Civil law in our country
